stories.text:
I always considered myself to be a "good" programmer. Been at it on and off for 20 years now. Have been building my own desktops for just as long.

That idealization lasted until I decided to tackle a massive software project on my own recently, and I'm feeling increasingly unconfident about my abilities.

The more example code I look at implementing, the more I realize just how spaghetti-like what-I-call-programming really is.

I have never had any formal programming education. I took a "Java for beginners" course in university once and dropped out after 2 weeks because everybody in the course seemed to already know everything about Java and I was entirely lost.

I am embarrassed to admit that I don't have the slightest idea what "object oriented" even means.

I have cracked open "Clean Code" recently and have made it half way through "The Pragmatic Programmer" a few years ago ... but can't even find that book anymore :S

Are those even good suggestions for someone like me?

How would you suggest to somebody who already thinks they're a good programmer to go about actually becoming a good programmer?

A bit about me...

- comfortable w/HTML+CSS 20 years go with a SAMS 24 hour book

- comfortable w/PHP 15 years ago with a PHP for Dummies book

- comfortable w/Javascript 15 years ago with the web

- comfortable w/Python 5 years ago through the web

- comfortable w/Node 2 years ago through the web

Thank you so much for reading this far. Really! I appreciate it!
